*   **Course Description:**

Intermediate Writing (I) aims to develop students’ writing skills and critical thinking through systematic writing practice. In this course, students will write different types of essays. Course time will be devoted largely to discussions of the structural components of narrative and expository writing, writing samples, common writing errors, and rhetoric strategies. In addition to lectures, this course will engage students in various writing activities, such as group discussion, peer review and editing.

*   **Course Objectives:**

At the end of this course, students will be able to

1.  identify the structural components of narrative and expository writing;
2.  employ different rhetoric strategies for various purposes in writing;
3.  articulate how audience expectation and writing purposes shape writing products;
4.  diagnose and edit their own essays.

*   **Delivery of instruction:**

1.  Lecture
2.  Group discussion & cooperation
3.  Peer review & editing
4.  Student presentation

*   **Grading Policy & Course Requirements:**

**1.     Grading Policy:**

    (1) Attendance, participation & engagement: 15%

    (2) Essays (including original drafts and revisions): 50%

    (3) Two writing podcasts: 10%

    (4) Assignments (e.g., essay outlines, peer review/feedback, others): 15%

    (5) Final podcaster project: 10%

**2\.  Writing Podcasts (10%)**

Writing podcasts are for students to introduce their own essays and reflect upon their writing process. Every student has to hand in two writing podcasts in this semester. More information about the requirements and evaluative criteria for writing podcasts will be announced in class.

**3.  Final Podcaster Project (10%)**

For this project, every student needs to play the role of a podcaster to introduce the three essays he/she completes in this semester. More information about the requirements and evaluative criteria for this podcaster project will be announced in class.

**4\. Classroom Policies:**

1.  Class attendance is a fundamental requirement that will be strictly enforced in this course. You are required to come to class every week. Absence from **each class period** will result in a 2-point deduction from your attendance/participation score (except with a valid excuse approved by the instructor). Arriving late to class or leaving early will also count as an absence. Your participation will also be scored based on how much you contribute to discussions.
2.  Please note that you are required to submit any of your assignments (including essays) before it is due. Late assignments will be marked down by **30%**. Once they are two or more days late, they will NOT be accepted. 
3.  Dishonesty: Academic dishonesty is a misconduct that occurs in academic exercises. It involves plagiarism, cheating, fabrication, etc. You will be penalized for academic dishonesty on any tests, assignments and exercises.

**5\. Textbook:**

1.  There is no set textbook for this course. Reading materials will be provided.
2.  Recommended materials:

Wyrick, J. (2014). _Steps to writing well_ (12th ed.). MA: Wadsworth.

Carlock, J., Eberhardt, M., Horst, J., & Menasche, L. (2010). _The ESL writer’s handbook_. Michigan: The University of Michigan Press.

Skwire, S. E., & Skwire, D. (2011). _Writing with a thesis: A rhetoric and reader_ (11thed.). MA: Wadsworth.

Free online lecture videos on Coursera ([https://www.coursera.org/](https://www.coursera.org/))
